Theatre Royal, May .Market*

To the Public.
From the John Hull newspaper of Oct, 1 5 .

"By your leave, ye majors! Leviathans though
ye be ! you are not the only fish that swim, nor the
most dainty. And this week at least, your rank
must give place to the higher order of merit. The
little theatre in the H a y m a r k e t may boast of having presented the public with many of the choicest
comedies that g r *ce the stage. H e r e FOOTE, COL>IAN, GOLDSMITH, have in turn first triumphed;
and broad satire, genuine humour, and playful wit
have endeared it as the seat of pleasant recollections. It has remained for SHERIDAN KNOWLES
to make it classic ground. The LOVE CHASE,
produced here on Monday, Oct. 9, from the pen of
this gentleman, will mark an epoch in its history,
ns it assuredly forms an era in modern dramatic
literature.
The acting of The LOVE CHASE is highly
relished by the audience, and, combined with the
pleasure of hearing language at once so poetic and
racy, affords a treat \s hich no one with pretensions
of love for the drama should grudge himself the
pleasure of seeing. W e should more than doubt
liiH enthusiasm in behalf of a healthy literature and
a rational amusement, *vho would regret his money
after the curtain fell."
VIVAT REGINA*
First Price—Boxes 5s.-Pit 3s.—Gallery 2s.-TJpper Gallery It.
Second Price at Nine o'Clock — Boxes 3s.-*it as—Gallery Is—Upper Gallery 6<1.
05* Place* for the Boxes may bo taken daily of Mr. Am use, at the Theatre, from II tofl o'clock,

Theatre Rnya1, Map

.Market.

To the Public
From the John Bull newapaper of Oct. 15.

"By your leave, ye majors! Leviathans though
ye be ! you are not the only fish that swim, nor the
most dainty. And this week at least, your rank
must give place to the higher order of merit. The
little theatre in the I lay market may boast of having presented the public with many of the choicest
comedies that gr<tce the stage. H e r e FOOTE, COLUAN, GOLDSMITH, Lave in turn first triumphed;
and broad satire, genuine humour, and playful wit
have endeared it as the seat of pleasant recollections. It has remained for SHERIDAN KNOWLES
(o make it classic ground. The LOYE C H A S E ,
produced here on Monday, Oct. 9, from the pen of
this gentleman, will mark an epoch in its history,
as it assuredly forms an era in modern dramatic
literature.
The acting of The LOVE CHASE is highly
relished by the audience, and, combined with the
pleasure of hearing language at oace so poetic and
racy, affords a treat which no one with pretensions
of love for the drama should grudge himself the
pleasure of seeing. W e should more than doubt
his enthusiasm in behalf of a healthy literature and
a rational amusement, who would regret his money
after the curtain fell."
VIVAT REQINAI

AND

it will be repeated To-night,

Four Times a Week until

TO-NIGHT, TO-MORROW, and SATURDAY.
W Mr. SERJEANT TALFOURD/S new Tragedy of The

Athenian Captive

Having, on its production at this She-tre, been honored with the
most enthusiastic approbation throughout, by crowded audiences
it will be repeated
To-night, and Saturday;
being the Last Nights but Four
that it can be performed this Season.
I n obedience t o t h e w i s h of the n u m e r o u i P a t r o n * of this Establishment,

Mr. MACREADT

will repeat the character of the Duke Aranza
In The HON F T MOtlN. for fhe second a n d Last Time

TOMORROW EVENING.

To the MHihlic.
OPINIONS OF THE P R E i i i
" Filial affection, or rather what may be called the
domestic feeling, in the lending feature of Knowles'
new play, The Maid of Martendorpt. and certain conceptions and situation* are perhaps more powerful
original, and striking-, than any thing he lias produced.
Loud and unanimous applause' followed the descent of
the curtain, and Knowlcs announced his drama for
repetition amid repeated acclamations."—The Timet" Knowlos' poetry is that of nature, while rt is characterized, at the name time, by those abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous
There is a fervour—a frankness in his style which we do
not rcoognize in any other modern author. There is a
genuine stamp of philaotbrophy impressed on every page,
•calculated at once to refine the feelings, and to ennoble
the man."—-TAeWseWy Ditpalth.
" Mr. Knowles has availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Village of Mariendorpt, and
treating it with • a liberal hand,' ha* made it effectively
subservient to hts purpose. The plot is strongly pathetic.
There was mach applause b . stssp.il nn the plav throiig-hout its ordeal, and at the end Knowles Was called limit
with general acclaim."—Morning Herald.
" It JR a composition of simple yet strong interest;
and with the smiles that it provokes it blends a pathos
that comes direct from the most ' sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' The natural interests of its situations,
particular scenes of humour and pathos, the poetical
character of the diction insure for it a popularity which
the author's exertions merit. Its announcement for
every evening was received with loud and unanimous
applause."—Morning Chronicle.
" As a dramatic work we like The Maid of Matifiidorpl more than The 1A>%* Chafe. Its plot is well
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry in
many passages full of abounding beauty, charity, and
human love. In its production Sheridan Knowles may
be said to have added another laurel to his head and to
his heart; and when his work closed with the usual indications of triumphant success, he was called for to
announce its repetition amid bursts of enthusiasm. Praise
is due for producing,— with such good appointments,
and such good acting,—so beautiful and attractive a
dramatic production."—Mommy Post.
" A s the story unfold«d, we felt assayed of its safety ;
»»d when the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth
acts, the audience seemed happy to relievo themselves
4f Hunt excited feelings ia overwhelming hurst* of
tflh»«te. The piece was eompjUsolv successful " - The
- Wh»« Kno.bjl same forward to announce- the repetition of A . pw»*> *fw audience greeted him with
acclamation*, wbieb TO*** have been ns grateful to fetfe
a . iSray are deserved by him.**— Tke fWoit.
" The talented author of lirgimm, The Hunchback,
The Love Chase, A c , has added fresh laurel* to his fame
in the production of another drama, of that elastic beauty,
philo-epliic: sublimity, and sterling1 eJuraeter which had
already woo for him the admiration and gratitude of a
discerning and delighted public. It afforded us, therefore, no small amount flSVpleasme to witness the zealous
» r f fervent enthusiasm wnich crowrwrt with success hi*
latest effort"—Shipping Gazelle.
" T t » play i* erawdad with fine things, worthy «f the
genius of Sheridan Know!.*."— Atlat-

" The discriminating public is again indebted to Mr.
Sheridan Knowles for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic genius which are imperishably interwoven with
his name upon the records of our dramatic literature.
The humanities never have been more delightfully pourtrayed than in this play. It is full of passage* of impassioned eloquence, and, as an effective drama appealing:
to our most holy sympathies, we consider it superior to
any of his former production*."—Weekly Chromele.
" Since the production of The Maid of Mariendorpl,
a few slight, but judicious alterations, have had the effect
of making the action of the drama go more harmoniously')
rendering it altogether more compact and united. Th*e
loves of Hans and Esther is the most laughable episode
imaginable, and were there nothing else in the play,
would make it run a season."—-Mormng Advertiser.
" The Maid of Mariendorpt is worthy of Mr. Knowles"
reputation a* a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of the scenes are
managed with the greatest dramatic skill, and is sure to
attain to great popularity."—The Observer.
T t » o iii«3iit -it ttHT iVc*tftf vf ATt»» SVNiS.* fl .. TT *h» *m*u

thai no living' author save Knowles could have written i t ;
and it would be difficult to point out anything- on the
stage finer than the whole of the fourth net. The gettingup of the piny reflects the highest credit on the management ; the dresses were admirable, and the whole of the
details carefully looked to. We doubt not but every one
who values a national poet and a national drama, will go
stnd see Ihe Maid of Murtendorpt, and give due honour*
to the author."—77ie Age.
" The object of the drsnwtiet has been to give a faithful
portrait of exalted filial:affection — the affection of a
daughter to a beloved and indulgent parent. The main
end of the drama is ts carry out and pourtrav this beautiful, this sublime feeling—alt our sensibilities are
interested—none of our senses excited—it is a play of the
heart and the mind. Another aim has been to" break
down tli. barriers of prejudice between the Jew and the
Christian; and the whoto of these effort* are successful
through a vein of poetry which seems gushing from die
fountain of the heart."—'•The Era.
" We need scarcely add, the play was perfectly ftto*
cessful. It had been carefully put upon the stage, and
Mr. Knowles, amid enthusiastic cheering, announced it
for repetition every evening."— The Examiner.
" The plot of thi* play t# ssrnple, but throughout the
piece interest is kept alive, until in the third act that
interest deepens, and is carried in the fourth to the highest
dramatic climax. It was received throughout most favourably by a crowded house, and at its close, the curtain fell
amid thunders of applause."—Sunday Times.
" We have nightly seen Mr. Knowles' new play of The
Maid of Martendarpt with increased pleasure,' and at
each repetition we have discovered fresh beauties, in
Wtker tiie sentiments expressed, or in the construction of
the dialogue."—The Crown.
" O n Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr. Sheridan
Knowles, and called The Maid of Mariendorpl, was
produced here with perfect success;—the author has
drawn it so intense, and wrought it out with so many
vivid beauties of poetry and striking stage tabkaua, that
we are hound to confess to it* having completely carried
tbe audience along to afinalt>attended by n e s t unanimous
applause, and, we have no doubt, will fill die house for
many a night to come."—IMerarf Gaxelle.

OPINIONS OF THE PRESS!
" Filial . f a c t i o n , or rather what may bo called t h e
domestic feeling-, in t h e leading feature ol Knowles'
new play, 'I he Maid of \fariendorpt,
and certain c o n ceptions and situation* a r e perhaps more |ionerful.
original, and striking, than any thing- h e h a s produced.
Loud and Hit.Milium applause followed the descent of
t h e curtain, a n d Knowles a n n o u n c e d his drama for
repetition amid repeated acclamations.''—The Timet.
" Knowles' poetry is that of n a t u r e , while it is characterized, a t t h e s a m e time, by thoae abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
T h e r e is a fervour—a frankness in his style which we do
not recognize in any oilier modern author. T h e r e is a
genuine stamp of phihinthrophy impressed on every p a g e ,
calculated at once to refine t h e feelings, and to ennoble
t h e man."—The Weekly
Dispatch.
" Mr. Knowles h a s availed himself of an incident in
Miss Po/ier's novel of The Village of Mariendorpt, and
treating- it with ' a liberal hand,' h a s made it effectively
subservient to his purpose. T h e plot is strongly pathetic.
T h e r e w as much a p p l a u s e bestow od o n the play t h r o u g h out its ordeal, a n d a t the end Knowles was called forth
with general acclaim."—Morning
Herald.
" I t is a composition of simple yet strong i n t e r e s t ;
and with t h e smiles that it provokes it blends a pathos
t h a t eomes direct from the most ' sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' T h e natural interests of its situations,
particular scenes of humour and pathos, t h e poetical
character of t h e diction insure for it a popularity which
t h e author's exertions merit.
I t s announcement for
every evening was received with loud and unanimous
a p p l a u s e " . — Morning
Chronicle.
" A s a dramatic work w e like The Maui nf
\farieriiorpi more than The IA>\I Chase.
Its plot is well
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry in
many passages full of abounding beauty, charity, and
human love. I n its production Sheridan Knowh-s may
be said to have added another laurel to his head and to
bis h e a r t ; and when his work closed with the usual indications of triumphant success, h e w a s called for to
announce its repetition amid hursts of enthuaia-tm. Praise
is d u e for p r o d u c i n g , — with such good appointments,
and such good acting,—so beautiful and attractive a
dramatic production."—Morning Post.
" As the story unfolded, w e felt assured of its safety ;
and when the curtain dropped upon t h e third end fourth
a c t s , the audience seemed happy t o relieve themselves
of their excited feelings in overwhelming bursts of
a p p l a u s e . T h e piece was completely successful.'"—The
Courier.
" When Knowles oaroo forward to announce the repetition of t h e piece, t h e audience greeteil him with
acclamations, which must have been a s grateful to him
as they are deserved by him."— The Globe.
" T h e talented author of Viruinius.
The
Hunchback,
The Lore Chase, & c , h a s adder! fresh laurels to his fame
in the production of another drama of that elastic beauty,
philosophic sublimity, and sterling character which had
already won for him t h e admiration a n d gratitude of a
discerning and delighted public. It afforded us, therefore, no small amount of pleasure to wituess the ».ealous
and fervent enthusiasm which crowned with success his
latest effort."—Shipping
Gazette.
" T h e piny is crowded with fine t h i n g s , worthy of t h e
g e n i u s of Sheridan Knowles."—Atlas.

" Tltc discriminating public is again indebted to Mr.
Sheridan Knowles for one of those sparkling- emanations
of poetic genius which are imperishobly interwoven with
his name upon t h e records of our dramatic literature.
The humanities never have beoti m o r e delightfully pourt rayed than in this play. It is full of passages of irapa-sioned e l o q u e n c e ; a n d , a s an effective drama appealing
to our most holy sympathies, we consider it superior to
any of his former productions " — W e e k l y
Chronicle,
" S i n c e the production of The Maid of
Manendorpt,
a few slight, but judicious alterations, have had the effect
of making the action of the drama g o more harmoniously,
rendering it altogether more compact and united. T h e
loves of H a n s and Esther is the most laughable episode
i m a g i n a b l e , and were there nothing else in t h e play,
would make it run a season."—Morning
Advertiser.
" The Maid of Maiiendorpt is worthy of Mr. Knowles'
reputation a s a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while soma of t h e scenes a r e
managed with the g r e a t e s t dramatic skill, and is sure t o
attain to g r e a t popularity."—The Observer.
" T h e merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt
is so great,
that no living author save Knowles could have written i t ;
and it would be difficult to point out anything on the
s t a g e finer than the whole of the fourth act. T h e g e t t i n g
up of t h e play reflects the highest credit on the m a n a g e ment ; t h e dresses were admirable, and the whole of t h e
details carefully looked to. W e doubt not but every one
who values a national poet and a national drama, will g(>
and see The Maid o / M a r i i n j l i t p t , mid give due honours
to the author."—The Age.
" The object of the dramatist has been t o give a faithful
portrait of exalted filial affection — t h e affection of a
d a u g h t e r to a beloved and indulgent parent. The main
end of t h e drama is- to carry out and pourtray this beautiful, this sublime fueling—ail our sensibilities a r e
interested—none of our senses excited—it is a play of the
heart ami t h e mind
Another aim h a s been to break
down the barriers of prejudice between the Jew ind t h e
Christina; and the whole of these efforts a r e successful
through a vein of poetry which seems g u s h i n g from t h e
fountain of the heart."—The lira.
" W e need scarcely add, t h e play was perfectly s u c cessful. I t hod beeu carefully put upon lire stage, and
Mr. Rnowlcs, amid enthusiastic cheering, announced it
for repetition every evening."'—The Exami-ner.
" T h e plot of this play is simple, b u t throughout t h e
piece interest is kept alive, until in t h e third act that
inttiest deepens, and is carried in the fourth to the highest
dramatic climax. ft was received t h r o u g h o u t most favourably by a crowded house, arid at its close, the curtain fell
H s u thunders of applause."—Sunday Times.
•' W e h*vs nightly seen Mr. Knowlcs' new play of Ike
Maid of Mai-tcndurpl
with increased pleasure, am) a t
each repetition we nave discovered fresh beauties, in
either the v.'iiliments expressed, or in the -onstruction of
the dialogue."—The Crown.
" On Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr. Sheridan
Know les, and" called The Maid of Mariendorpt,
was
roduced here with perfect s u c c e s s ; — t h e author h a s
drawn it so intense, and wrought it out with so many
vivid beauties of poetry and striking s t a g e tableaux, that
we are bound to confess to its having completely carried
the audience a l o n g to a finale attended by most unanimous
applause, and, we have no doubt, will fill t h e house for
many a u i g h t to come."—Ltferary
Gazette.

IHr. S H E R I D A I t f

KIVOWLES'

SUCCESSFUL AND POPULAR NEW PLAY O F THE

naidofHariendorpt
EVEXSY

EVENING

To the JPubtic.
OPINIONS OF THE PRESS •
" Filial affection, or rather what may ha culled thu
domestic feeling-, is the leading feature of Knowles'
new ploy, Ike Maid of Mariendorpt, and curtain conceptions and situations are perhaps more powerful,
original, and striking, than any thing he has produced.
Lnud and unanimous applause followed the descent of
%bo curtain, and Knowles announced his drama for
repetition amid repeated acclamations. '—The Times.
" Knowles' poetry is that of nature, while it ia characterized, at the same time, hy those abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
There is a fervour—a frankness in his stvle which »e do
not recognize in any other modern author. There is a
genuine stamp of phiUnthrophy impressed on every page,
calculated at once to refine the feelings, and to ennoble
the man.''—TheH'eekly Dispatch.
" Mr. Knowlcs has availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Village of Mariendorpt. and
treating it with ' a liberal hand,1 has mnile it effectively
subservient to his purpose. The plot is strongly pathetic.
There was much applause bestowed on the play throughout its ordeal, and at the end Knowles was called forth
with general acclaim."—Morning Herald.
" It is a composition of simple yet strong interest;
anil with the smileR that it provokes it blends a pathos
that comes direct from the most ' sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' The natural interests of its situation*,
particular scenes of humour and pathos the poetical
character of the diction insure for it a popularity which
the author's exertions merit. Its announcement for
every evening- was received with loud and unanimous
applause "—Morning Chronicle.
" As a dramatic work we like Tlie Maul of Maii'Vdorpt more than The Love Chnse. Its plot i« well
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry in
many passages full of abounding- beauty, chaiity, and
human love. In its production Sheridan Knowles may
be said to have added another laurel to his head and to
his heart; and when hi» work closed with the USIIHI indications of triumphant success, he was called for lo
announce its repetition amid bursts of enthusiasm. Praise
it due for producing,— with such growl appointments,
and such good acting,—so beautiful ttm! attractive a
dramatic production."—Morning Post.
" As the story unfolded, we felt assured of its safety;
and when the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth
acts, the audience seejnea happy to relieve themselves
of thoir excited feelings in overwhelming bursts of
rpplause. The piece was completely successful."—The
Courier.
" When Kno-vles came forward to announce the repetition of the piece, the audience greeted him with
acclamations, which must have been as grateful to him
us they are deserved by him."'—Ike Globe.
" Tho talented aulhor of Virqmius. The Hmekback,
The Lot* Chase, A c , has added fresh laurels to hi* fame
to the production of another drama of that elastic beauty,
philosophic sublimity, and sterling character which had
already won for him" the admiration and gratitude; of a
discerning and delighted public. It afforded as, therefore, no small amount of pleasure to witness the zealous
and ftirvetit enthusiasm which crowned with success his
latest effort."—Shipping Gasulte.
" The phty is crowded with fine things, worthy of the
genius of Sheridan Knowlet.'"—Atlas.

" The discriminating public ia again indebted lo Mr
Sheridan Knowles for one ef those sparkling emanations
of poetic genius which are imperi«hal>ry interwoven with
his name upon the records of our dramatic literature.
The humanities never have been more delightfully pourtrayed than in this play. It is full of passage* of impassioned eloquence | and, as an effective drama appealing
lo our most holy sympathies, we consider it superior to
any of his former productions "—Weekly Chronicle.
" Sinee the production of The Maid of Mariendorpt,
a few slight, but judicious alterations, have had the effect
of making the action of the drama go more harmoniously,
rendering it altogether more compact and united. The
loves of Huns and Esther is the most laughable episode
imaginable, and were there nothing else in the play,
would make it run a season."—Morning Advertiser.
" The Maid of Mariendorpt is worthy of Mr. Knowles'
reputation as a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of the scenes are
managed with the greatest dramatic skill, and is sure te
attain to great popularity."—The Observer.
" The merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt \*m great,
that no living author save Knowles could have written it;
and it would be difficult to point out anything on th*
stage finer than the whole of the lourth aet. TTiji getting
up of the play refleiits the highest credit on the management ; the dresses were admirable, and t h . whole of the
details, carefully looked to. We doubt not hut every one
who values a national poet and a national drama, will go
and see Ihe Maid of Mariendorpt, and give due honours
to the author."—The Age.
" The object of the dramatist has been to cive a faithful
portrait of exalted fi!i::l affection — the affection of a
liuughlei to a beloved ;-nd indulgent parent. The main
end of the drama is to curt} cut and pourtrzy this beautiful, this sublime feeling—all our sensibilities are
interested—none of our senses excited—it is a play of tho
heart and the mind. Another aim has been to break
down tie I timers of prejudice between the Jew and the
Christian; and the whole of these efforts are successful
through n vein of poetry which seems gushing from the
fountain of the heart."— The Era.
" We need scarcely add, the play was perfectly successful. It had been carefully put upon the stage, and
Mr. Know lee, amid enthusiastic cheering, announced it
for repetition every evening."—The Examiner.
" The plot of this play is simple, but throughout the
piece interest is kept nine, until in the third act that
interest deepens, and is carried in the fourth to the highest
dramatic climax. It was received throughout most favourably by a crowded housej and-at its close, the curtain fell
amid thunders of applause."—Sunday Times.
" We have nightly seen Mr. Knowles' new piny of The
Maid of Mariendorpt with increased pleasure," and at
each repetition we nave discovered fresh beauties, in
either the sentiments expressed, or in the construction of
the dialogue."—The Crown.
'• On Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr. Sheridan
Knowles, and called The Maid of Mariendorpt, was
produced here with perfect success;—the author has
Srawn it so intense, and wrought it out with so many
vivid beauties of poetry and striking stage tableaux, that
we are bound to confess to its having completely carried
the audience along to a finale attended hy most unanimous
applause, and, we have no doubt, will fill the house for
many a night to come."—Literary Gazette.

To the Public.
©PINIONS OF THE PRESS s
'* Filial affection, or rather what may be called the
domestic fcelittg, in the leading feature of Knowles'
now play, Ik* Maid of Mariendorpt, and certain conception* and situations arc perhaps mora powerful,
original, and striking, than any thing- he has produced.
Loud and unanimous applause followed the descent of
the curtain, and Knowlcs announced his drama for
repetition amid repeated acclamations.'— Tkt TtWi.
" Kttovrles' poeWJt "is 'that of mature, while it i« ehaWteiwed, at the same time, by those abstract tjunlitta.
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
Tht*re ii a fervour—a frank'ness in his sty's which we do
not recognise in any olher modern author. There is a
genuine stamp of phthmthrophy impressed on every p»ge>
calculated nt once to refine the feelings, and to ennoble
the man."—The Weekly Dispatch.
" Mr. Knoules has availed himself of an incident in
Mi«* Poller's novel of The Village of \farienifor>,t, ami
treating it with ' a liberal hand,' ha* made it effectively
subservient to his purpose. The plot is strongly pathetic.
There was much applause bestowed on the put" throughout its ordeal, and at the end Knowlaa was called forth
with general acclaim."—Morning Herald.
" It is » composition of simple yet strong interest;
and with the smites that it provokes it blends a pathos
that comes direct from the most * sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' The natural interests of its situations,
particular scenes of humour and pathos, Hie poetical
character of the diction insure for it a popularity which
the authors exertions merit. Its anuouncsmeiit for
e\ery evening was received with loud and unanimous
applause "—Murning Chronicle,
" As a dramatic woik we like The Maid of M-trirndorpt more than The fare Chase. Its pint U well
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry in
many passages full of ahoutniintr beauty, charily, and
human love. In its production Sheridan Known* may
he snid to have added another laurel to his head mid to
his heart; and when his work closed with the usual indications of triumphant success, he was called for to
mnounce its repetition amid hursts of enthusiasm , Praise
i< due for producing,— with such good appointments,
end such good acting,—so beautiful and attractive a
dramatic production."—Morning Post.
" As the story unfolded, we felt assured of its safety ;
and whon the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth
acts, the audience SO i ied happy to relieve themselves
of their excited feelings in overwhelming bursts of
applause. The piece was completely successful."—The
(^ourier.
" When KoO'vfes came forward to announce the repetition of the piece, the audience greeted him with
acclamations, which must have been as grateful to him
s they are deserved by him.'—The Globe.
" The talented author of Virtjmiiu, The Hunchback,
The Lore Chase, &c, has added fresh laurels tu his fame
in the production of another drama of that elastic beauty,
i'hilosophie sublimity, and sterling character which had
already won for him the admiration and eratitude of a
discerning and delighted public. It afforded us, the»e~
fore, no small amount of pleasure to witness the zealous
and fervent enthusiasm which crowned with success his
latest effort."—Skipping Gazette.
" The play is crowded with fine things, worthy of the
genius of Sheridan Knowles."—Atlas.

" l l i c disorinsina^Bg- public is again indebted to Mr.
Sheridan Knowies for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic genius which are imp< rishably interwoven witli
bis name upon the records of our dramatic literature.
The humanities never have been more dcligbt/uily pourtrayed than in this play. It is full of passages of impassioned eloquence; arid, as an effective drama appealing
to «ur most fcoly sympathies, we consider it superior *o
any of his former productions."—- Weekly Gkromctt.
" Since the production of Th* Maid <$ Mariendorpt,
"» few slight, but judicious alterations, have had the effect
of making the action of the drama go more harmoniously,
rendering it altogether more compact and united. T b .
loves of Hans and Esther is tha most laughable eptsodo
imaginable, and were theft nothing else in the play,
would make it run a season."—Mermng Advertiser.
" The Maid of MaiitnJorpt is worthy of Mr. Knowlet.
reputation as a dramatic w riter. it sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of the scenes ate
managed with the greatest dramatic skill, and is sure to
attain to great popularity,"—The Observer.
" The merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt is so great
that no living author save Koo'wles could have written i t ;
and n would bo difficult to point out anything on fh«
stage finer than the whole of the fourth act." I he getting
up of the plav i« fleets the highest credit on the management ; the dresses were admirable, and the whole of tlie
details carefully looked to. Wo doubt not but every one
who values a national poetanda national drama, will go
and see The Maid r.f Mariendorpt, and sjite due honours
to the author."—Thr Age,
•' The object of the dramatist has been to give a faithful
portrait of ejalted fijial affceuon — the affectioa of a
daughter to a belovod un 1 indulgent parent. The main
end of the drama Ut to carry out and pounray this beautiful, this sublime feeling—all our sensibilities are
interested—none of our senses excited—it is a play of the
heart and the mind. Another aim has been to" break
clou n the barriers of prejudice between the Jew and the
Christianj and the whole of these efforts are successful
through a rein of poetry which seems gushing from the
fountain of the heart."—T%e Era.
" We need scarcely add, the play was perfectly successful, h had been carefully put upon the stage, and
Mr. hnowles, amid enthusiastic cheering, announced it
for repetition every evening."—The Examiner.
" The plot of this play is simple, but throughout the
piece interest is kept alive, until in the third act that
interest deepens, and is carried in the fourth to the highest
dramatic c-lurmx. It was received throughout most favourably bv a crowded house, and at its close, the curtain fell
amid thunders of applause."—Sunday Times.
" We have nightly seen Mr. Kliowles' new play of The
Maid of Mariendorpt with increased pleasure," and at
each repetition we Slave discovered fresh beauties, in
either the sentiments expressed, or in the construction of
the dialogue.'—The Crown.
"On Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr, Sheridan
Knowles, and called fhe Maid of Mariendorpt, was
produced here with perfect success;—the author has
drawn it m Intense, and wrought it out with so many
vvvtd beauties of poetry and striking stage tableaux, that
w e a r s bound to confess to its having completely earned
the audience along to a finale attended by most unanimous
applause, and, we have no doubt, will fill Jie house for
many « night to come."—Literary Gasetle,

To ihe MhibMe.
OPINION!-! O F
" Filial affection, or rather what may lie (tilled lite
domestic feeling, is t h e leading feature ol K n o n l e s '
new play, The Maid * / Maritnderpt,
and certain conceptions and situation* a r e perhaps more powerful,
original, and striking, than any thinsf lie ha« produced.
Loud and unanimous applause* follow ed the descent of
t h e curtain, and Knnwle* announced hi* drama for
repetition amid repeated acclamation*. '—The
Times.
" Krtowle*' poetry i» that of n a t u r e , while it i* characterized, at t h e same time, by t h o s e abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
Tlrere is a fervour—a frankness in hi* stvle which we do
not recognise in any other modern author. T h e r e is a
genuine stamp of pluhmthrophv impressed on every p a g e ,
calculated at once to refine the feelings, and to cunoYile
the man."—TheWeekly
Dispatch.
" Mr. hlnowles has availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Villaqe of Mariendorpt,
and
treating it with ' a liberal hand,' has made it effectively
subservient to his purpose. T h e plot is strongly pathetic.
T h e r e was much applause bestowed on the play t h r o u g h out its ordeal, a n d a t the end Koowles was tailed forth
with general acclaim."—Morning
Herald.
" It is a composition of Mirtple yet strong i n t e r e s t ;
and with the smiles that it provoke" it blends a riathos
that comes direct from the most ' snifcd fount of sympathetic tears.' The natural interests of its situitions,
particular scenes of h u m o u r and pathos, t h e poetical
character of t h e diction insure for it a popularity which
t h e a u t h o r s exertions merit.
Its announcement for
every eveninjr was received with loud und unanimous
applause "—MtirniKij
Chronicle.
" As a dramatic work we like T V Mmd of Marie*dorf.il more than The fjr** Vhtse.
fts ploi is will
imagined, its interest well sustained, a n l it** poetry in

and when the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth

is «o g r e a t ,
that no living author save Knowles could have written i t ;

detail* gar »fuliy looked to. W e doubt not but every one

" T h e object of the dramatist has been t o give a faithful
p o r t r a t of exalted filial affection—the affection of a

piece interest is kept alive, until in the third act that

dramatic climax. It was received throughout most favourably hy a crowded house, and at iis close, the curtain fell
amid thunders of applause."—Sunday Times.

Maid of Marundorpt
with increased pleasure," and at

OPINIONS OF THE PRESH I
" Fili.1 affection, o r rather what sany b e called rbe
d e m e s n e feeling i* t h e leading feature ul Knowtes'
new pfae. The Maid of Maritiukrpt,
and eurtuin conceptions »nd situations a r c perhaps more powerful,
original, and striking, than . « y tiling h e ha* produced.
Loud and unanimous applause followed t h e descent of
the curtain, and Knowles announced his drama for
repetition amid repeated a c c l a m a t i o n s . ' — T h t
Timet.
" Knowlos' poetry i* that of nature, w h i l . it is characterized, a t t h e s a m e time, by those aittratt
ipi-lities
which almost render fancy and philosophy uialsffnrs.
T h e r e i» a fervour—a frankness in bin style which we t o
pot recognize in any other modern author. T h e r e is a
genuine stamp of phtlanthrophy impressed on every p a g e ,
calculated a t once t o refine t h . feeling's, and t o ennoble
t h e man.*—Thctfeeklg
Dispatch.
" Mr. Knowles h a s availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Village of Mariendorpt, and
treating- it with ' a liberal hand, h a s made it effectively
subservient to his purpose. T h e plot is strongly pathetic.
T h e r e EWE much applause bestowed on the play t h r o u g h out it» ordeal, a n d a t the end Knowles was called forth
with general acclaim."—Morning
Herald.
" It is a composition of simple y e t strong i n t e r e s t ;
and with t h e smiles that it provokes it blends a p a t h o s
that comes direct from t h e most ' sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' T h e natural interests of its situations,
particular scene* of humour and pathos, t h e poetical
character of t h e dioti.n insure for it a popularity which
t h e author's exertions merit.
I t s announcement for
every evening was received with loud and unanimous
applause " — M o r n i n g
Chronicle.
" As a dramatic work wo like The Maid nf Martendorpt more than The IJOX* Chase.
I t s plot is well
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry : I
manv passages full of abounding beauty, charity, and
human love. I n its production Sheridan Kiiowles may
be said to have added another laurel to his bead aud to
his heart | and when his work d a t e d with the usual indication* of triumphant success, b e was called for to
announce its repetition amid hursts of enthusiasm. Praise
is d u e for producing",— with such good appointments,
and such good acting,—so beautiful a n d attractive a
dramatic production."—Morning Post.
" As the story unfolded, we felt assured of its safety;
and when the curtain dropped upon t h e third and fourth
acta, t h e audience seemed h a p p y t o relieve themselves
of their excited feelings in overwhelming hursts of
a p p l a u s e . T h e piece was completely successful "—The
Conritr.
" W h e n Knowles came forward t e announce the r e p e tition of t h e pnree, t h e audience greeted him with
acclamations, which must have been a s grateful to una
as they afe deserved by h i m . " — I h e Ghhe.
" T h e t«lcnted author of Virginian, The
Hunchback,
Tht Lor* Chmm, &<>., has added fresh laurels t o his fame
in the production of another drama ef that elastic beaut ,
philosophic sublimity, a n d sterling character which had
already w e . ft* him t h e admiration and gratitutre of a
discerning and delighted public. It afforded »», therefore, no (Wall amount of pleasure t o witness the r,ealou«
and fervent enthusiasm which crowned with success his
latest effort."~-S'i«>/'iiy
Gazette.
" T h e play i s crowded with fin. t h i n g s , worthy o f the
genius of Sheridan Knowles."—jftlrw.

" T h e discriminating puWic is r.rnin indebted t o M r .
Sheridan Know lea for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic genius which a r e impcrishably interwoven with
his name upon t h e record* of o u r d.omatie literature.
T h e humanities never have been m o r e delightfully p o u r trayed than in this play. I t is full of p . ssages* of impassioned e l o q u e n c e ; and, a s a . effective drama appealing
to our most holy sympathies, w e consider it superior t o
a n y of bis former productions."—fVeeklg
Chronicle.
" Since the production of The Mail' of
Mariendorpt,
a few slight, but judicious alterations, have had t h e effect
of m a k i n g the action of the drama g o more harmoniously,
rendering it altogether more compact and united. T h e
loves of H a n s and Esther is the must l a u g h a b l e episode
i m a g i n a b l e , and were there nothing else in t h e play,
would make it run a season."—Morning
Advertiser.
" The Maid of Mariendorpt is worthy of Mr. K n o w l e s '
reputation a s a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of t h e scenes a r e
managed with the g r e a t e s t dramatic skill, and is sure t o
attain t o great popularity."—The Observer.
" T h e merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt
is so g r e a t ,
that no living- author save Knowles could have written i t ;
and it would b e difficult to point Out anything on t h e
s t a g e finer than the whole of the fourth act." T h e g e t t i n g
u p of t h e play reflects the highest credit on t h e r.-nnag-em e n t ; t h e dresses were admirable, and the whole of t h e
details carefully looked to. W e doubt not but every one
who values a national poet and a national drama, will g o
and see The Maid of Martendoifit,
and give due honours
to the author."— The Age.
" T h e object of ihe dramatist has been to giw> a faithful
portrait of exalted filial affection — t h e affection of a
d a u g h t e r to a beloved and indulgent, parent. T h e main
end uf t h e drama is to carry out and pourtray this beautiful, this sublime feeling—all our sensibilities a r e
interested—none of our senses e x c i t e d - i t is a . J a y of the
iienrt and the mind. Another aim h a s been to break
down the harriers of prejudice between the Jew and t h e
Christianj and the whole of these efforts a r e successful
through a vein of poetry which seems g u s h i n g from t h e
fountain of the heart."— The Era.
" W e need scarcely add, t h e play was perfectly s u c cessful. It had been carefully put upon the s t a g e , and
Mr. k n o w l c s , amid enthusiastic cheering, announced it
for repetition every evening."—The
Examiner.
" T h e plot of this play is simple, but throughout t h e
piece interest is kept alive, until in t h e third act that
interest di-epens, and is carried in t h e fourth t o the highest
dramatic climajt. It was received throughout most favourably by a crowded house, and a t its close, the curtain fell
amid thunders of applause." - -Sunday
Timet.
" W e have nightly seen Mr. Knowles' new play of The
Maid of Martenderpt
with increased pleasure, and a t
each repetition we have discovered fresh beauties, in
eitlier the sentiments expressed, or in the construction of
the dialogue."—The Crown.
" On Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr. Sheridan
Knowlos, and called The Maid of Mariendorpt,
was
produced here with perfect s u c c e s s ; — t h e author h a s
drawn it so intense, and w r o u g h t it out with so many
vivid beauties of poetry and striking s t a g e tableaux, t h a t
we a r e bound to confess to its having- completely carried
d i e audience a l o n g t o a finale attended by most unanimous
applause, and, w e have no doubt, will fill the h o u s e for
many a night to oome."—Literary Gazette.

OPINIONS OF VIIE

" Filial affection, or rather what may I * tailed tit.
•tomestie feeling, ia the leading feature ill Knowhss'
new piny, The Maid of Marundorpt, unil curtain conceptions and situations art- perhaps mora powerful,
iriginal, and striking, titan any thing It. (tan produced.
Loud and unanimous npplanse followed the descent of
the rnrtain, and Knowles announced his drama for
••petition amid repeated acclamation*. '—The Timet.
" Knowtes' poetry ia that of nature, while it ia clmracteri*ed, at the same time, by those abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
There is a fervour—a frankness in his style which we do
not recogniee in anv other modern author. There is a
enuine stamp of phtlnnthrophy impressed on every page,
.calculated at nnee to refine the feelings, and to ennoble
the man."—7'ac/fVe kly IHtpatch.
" Mr. Knowles has availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Tillage of Mariendornt, and
treating it with ' a liberal hand,' has made it cffectiyelv
'iibaervieot to his purpose. The plot is strongly pathetic.
There was much applause bestowed m the play throught ut its ordeal, and at the end Know les was called forth
with general acclaim.''—Morning Herald.
" It is a composition of simple yet strong interesti
and with the smiles that it provokes it blends a pathos
'lint comes direct from the most ' sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' The natural interests of its situations,
particular scenes of humour and pathos, the poetical
character of the diction insure for it a popularity which
the author's exertions merit. Its announcement for
every evening- was received with loud and unanimous
applause "—Morning Chronicle.
" As a dramatic work we like The Maid of Marteniorpt more than 7he l.o e Chase. Its plot is well
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry in
I'tnnv passages full of *houii<linir beauty, charity, ami
human love. In its production Sheridan Knowles may
be said to have added another laurel to his bead and to
lis heart; and when his work closed with the. usual indication, of triumphant success, he was called for to
>!itiounec its repetition amid hursts of enthusiasm. Praise
i due for producing,—* with such (rood appointments,
'(id such good acting,—so beautiful and attractive a
•ii amatic production."—Morning Pout.
" At the story unfolded, we felt assured of its safety;
and when the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth
sola, the audience seemed happy to relieve themselves
of their excited feelings in overwhelming hursts of
applause. The piece was completely successful."—The

PISH,

- The discriminating public is again indebted to Mr.
Sheridan Kttowles for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic genius w bich are imperishabry interwoven with
Ids name upon the record, of our dramatic literature
T h . humanities never hate been more delightfully pourt rayed than in this play. It u foil of passages of impassioned eloquence; and, aa an effective drama appealing
to our moat holy sympathies, we consider it superior to
any of his former productions."—Weekly Chronicle.
" Sine, the production of The Maid of Martendorpt,
afewslight, but judicious alterations, have had the effect
of making- the action of the drama go more harmoniously,
rendering it altogether more compact and united. T b .
loves of Hans and Esther is the most laughable episode
imaginable, and were there nothing rise is the play,
would make it run • season."—Morning Advertiter.
" Tht Maid of Maitcndorpt i* worthy of Mr. Knowles'
reputation as a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of the scenes are
managed with the greatest dramatic skill, and is sure to
attain to great popularity,"—731* Observer,
" The merit of Tht Maid of Mariendorpt is so great,
that no living author save Knowlea could have written i t ,
and it would be difficult to point out anything on the
stage finer than the whole of the fourth act. The getting
ap of the play reflects the highest credit on the manage
ment; the dresses were admirable, and the whole of the
details carefully looked fo. We doubt not but .very one
who values a national poet and a national drama, will go
and see The Maid of Mariendorpt, and give due honours
to the author."—The Age.
" The object of the dramatist has been to give a faithful
portrait of ettahcii filial affection — the affection of a
daughter to a beloved and indulgent parent. The main
end of the drama is to'carry out and pourtrny this beautiful, this sublime feeling—all our sensibilities are
interested—none of our senses excited—it is a play of the
heart and the mind. Another aim has been to break
down the barriers of prejudice between the Jew and the
Christian; and the whole of these efforts are successful
through n vein of poetry which seems gushing from the
fountain of the heart."— The Era.
" W e need scarcely add, the play was perfectly suc-

Mr. SHERIDAN KMTOWIiES'
SUCCESSFUL AND POPULAR NEW PLAY OF THIC

MaidofEarieRdorpt
nirrnir rrjEwiNC.

To the Ihtbiie.
OPINIONS OF TIIK
" Fifial affection, or rather what may be colled Iris
domestic fueling, is the leading feature of kDO«le*
new piny, Ike Maid of Mariendorpt, and certain conception* and situations are perhaps more powerful,
original, and striking-, than any thing- he li»aproduced.
Lund and unanimous applause followed the descent of
the curtain, and Knowle* announced his drama for
repetition amid repeated acclamations.'—Tk* Time).
" Knowles' poetry is that of nature, while it is characterized, at the same time, by those abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
There i, a fervour—a frankness in hia atyte which we do
not recognize in any other modern author. There is a
genuine stamp of phtlenthrophy impressed on every page,
calculated at onee to refute the feeling'*, and to ennoble
the man."—Theffeekly
Dispatch.
" Mr. Knowle* has availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Village of Marieatfarpt, and
treating it with * a liberal hand, has made it effectively*
subxorwenl to his purpose. The plot is strongly pathetic.
There was much applause bestowed on the play throughout its ordeal, and at the end Knowle* w«* called forth
with general acclaim.''—Mormng .Herald.
" It is a composition of simple yet strong interest;
•and with the smiles that it provoke* it blends a pathos
that comae direct from the most ' sacred fount of sympathetic tears.' The natural interest? of its situations,
particular scenes of humour and pathos, the poetical
character of the diction insure for it a popularity which
the author's exertions merit. Its announcement for
everv evening- was received with loud and unanimous
applause."—Morning Chronicle.
" A* a dramatic work we like The Maid of Mariendorpt more than The Let* Chant. It* plot is well
•magined, its interest well sustained, and it« poetry in
many passages full of abounding beauty, charity, and
human love. In its production Sheridan Knowles maytie said to have added another laurel to his bead mid to
his heart; and when hi* work Closed with the usual indication* of triumphant success, he wsi* called for to
-enounce its repetition amid hursts of enthusiasm. Praise
'» due for producing,— i>rith such good appointment*.
md such good acting,—so beautiful and attractive a
dramatic production."—Morning Post.
" A* the story unfolded, we felt assured of its safety;
MI! when the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth
nets, the audience seemed happy to relieve themselves
of their excited feeling* in overwhelming burst* of
ipplause. Tho piece was completely successful."—The
Vomrier.
" When Knowles came forward to announce the repetition of the piece, the audience greeted him with
wclamalions, which must have been as grateful to him
as-atajgr.af. deserved by him."—The Globe.
" T h . talented author of Virainius, The Hunchback,
The Lot* Chat*, he,, has added freah laurels to hi* fame
ti the production of another drama of that elastic beauty,
philosophic sublimity, and- sterling character which had
'dread" won for him the admiration and gratitude of a
Warning and delighted public ft afforded us, therelore, no email amount of pleasure to witness the ttealoa*
on! fervent enthusiasm which crowned with success his
!
test effort."-- Shipping Ghiuttie.
"_Tb« play is crowded with i n * thing*, worthy of the
genius of Sheridan Knowles."™-Athu.

PRESS* f

" The discriminating public is again indebted to Mr.
Sheridan Know hi-, for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic geniu* which are imperislmbly interwoven with
hia name upon the records of our dramatic literature
The humanities never have been more delightfully pourtrayed than in this play, It is full of passages of impassioned eloquence; and, as an effective drama appealing
to our moat holy sympathies, we consider it superior to
nny of hi* former productions "—fFeekly Chronicle.
"Since the production of The Maid of Marienthrpt,
ft few slight, but judicious alterations, hate had the effect
of making- the action of the drama go more harmoniously,
rendering it altogether more compact ami united. Tlio
loves of Hans and Esther is the most laughable episode
imaginable, and were there nothing else in the play,
would make it run a season."—Morning Advertiser.
" The Maid of Mariendorpt is worthy of Mr. Know'les'
reputation as a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic
beauties throughout, while some of the scenes are
managed with the greatest dramatic skill, and is sure to
attain to great popularity."~~7*Ae Observer.
" The merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt is so great.
that no living author save Knowjes could have written it ;
and it would be difficult to point out anything on the
stage finer than the whole of the fourth act." The getting
up of tho play reflects the htSfliest credit on the management ; the dresses Were admirable, and the whole of tho
detail* carefully looked to. We doubt not but every one
who values a national poet mid a national drama, will go
and see The Maid of Mariendorpt, and give due honours
to the author."—The Age.
" The object of the droniaiUt has been to give a faithful
portrait of exalted filial affection — the aflbetion of a
daughter to a beloved and indulgent parent. The main
end of the drama is to carry out and pourtrav this beautiful, this sublime feeling—ell our sensibilities are
interested—none of our senses excited—it is a plav of the
heart and the mind. Another aim has been to" break
down the barriers of prejudice between the Jew and the
Christian; and the whole of these efforts are successful
through a vein of poetry which seems gushing from the
fountain of the heart."—The lira.
" Wo need rscarcely add, the play was perfectly successful. Jt had been carefully put upon the stage, and
Mr. Knowles, umid enthusiastic cheering, announced it
for repetition every evening."—The Examiner,
" The plot of this play is simple, but throughout the
piece interest is kept alive, until in the third act that
interest deepens, and is carried in the fourth to the highest
dramatic climax. Itwas received throughout most fnvojir
ably by a crowded house, and at its close, tho curtain fell
amid thunder;) of applause."—Sunday Timet.
" We have nightly seen Mr. Knowles' new play of The
Maid of Martendorpt with increased pleasure, and at
each repetition we have discovered fresh beauties in
either the sentiments expressed, or in the construetio'n of
the dialogue. —The Crown.
" On Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr. Sheridan
Knowles, and called The Maid of Mariendorpt, wa<.
produced here with perfect success;—the author has
drawn it so intense, and wrought it out with so many
vivid beauties of poetry and striking stage tableaux, that
we are bound to confess to its having completely carried
the audience along to » finale attended by moat unanimous
applause, and, we have no doubt, will fill the hou*. for
many a night to come-"—Literary Gazette.

W, S. JOHNSON, ".NASSAU PRESS," a, NASSAU KTRKET, SOHO

Theatre

Mr. P © W E R .

H r . W E B S T £ i t begs leave most respectfully to inform the Public, that
• a arrangement was entered into with the accredited agent of Mr.
P O W E R to perform here on Bee. the 5 t h . ; Mr. P . purposing to leave
Mew f o r k by the «Kreat Western steam ship on the 22nd of Nov., which
had she performed the voyage in twelve days and a half as she had done
eviously with a n adverse wind, would have enabled him to have
Ifllled his contract; but from some unforeseen circumstance, his departure from that city was delayed until the 3 4 t h ; whence he would
sail for Liverpool in one of the regular packets, called T1IB ROSCIUS.
H e Is consequently hourly expected, and every publicity will be given
of his arrival.
To atone for the disappointment, Mr. W . has succeeded in engaging

K

TOR S I X NIGHTS ONLY,
The celebrated American Comedian,

MM*,

Ho justly popular for his delineation of Yankee peculiarities, and he
wifl appear In two of his favorite characters every evening.

•till lingers amongst the peasantry, one orihe most poetical of our national eaperstiliona, and highly congenial to the temperament of en imagined,',- people.

awakes once more to a working day world, existing only In the creations of a wild fellow's brain fired by whiskey, snd disordered by hard blows His
imaginary perils anil sufferings being at once the consequence of his intemperance, and the mora! punishment of the relapsed whiskey loser.

ftj- There It hardly a looely asllay or wlidraountnlii rane;e In all Ireland, that Is not characterized bl K M denoting tbe residence, or haunt of the •'GoOO
h w r , o < F A I . I M , " and the belief tbat llieMe'^n inhabitants ef rerlh and air occasionally condescend to interfere with mortals either in mirth orinmalaee,
•dll lingers amongst the peasantry, one oHhe most poetical of our national superstition!, and highly congenial to the temperament of an imaginative people.
This Drama, huweeer, presents Ihe •• (joo.l People" io tin am only, the action of the piece, from the time the fairies appear, until the sleeping fVKIannina
awakes once more to a working day world, existing only In the creations of a wild fellow's brain fired by whiskey, and disordered by hard blows His
imaginary perils and sufferings being at once tbe consequence of his intemperance, and the moral punishment of the relapsed whiskey loser.

( f y There is hardly a lonel) rallev or wild mountain range in all Irotand, that is not characters.-,l b , n i n e denoting tbe residence, or haunt of the " G . 9 0
P a o r t s , o n FAinms.'' and llie belief that these elfin inhabitant, of rarth and air occasionally condmcendto interfere with mortals, either in mirth or in malar*
still lingers atnoCRSl the peasantry, one of the most poetical of our national soperstitl/>n», and hiRhly congenial to the temperament of an imsginatlse people!
'litis Drama, however, presrnt.s the " Good People" in dream only, lite action of the piece, from the time the fairies appear, until the sleeping O'Fiannigas*
awakes floee more to a working day world, existing only in the creations of a wild fellow's brain fired by whisker, and disordered b , h a r j blows. H t i
HMSgiuery perils and suffering* bring at on, e the consequence of his intemperance, ami the mora! punishment of tbe relapsed whiskey loser.
